title: أَقْسَامُ الْعَلَمِ
description: Learn about the different categories of proper nouns (الأعلام) in Arabic: العلم المنقول، العلم المرتجل، العلم بالغلبة، اللقب والكنية.

notes.title: What is العَلَم?
content: الْعَلَم (proper noun) is a word that designates a specific individual entity - a person, place, animal, or thing - without needing additional description. It is مَعْرِفَة (definite) by itself.

Arabic grammarians classify proper nouns into several categories based on their origin, formation, and usage. Understanding these categories helps in comprehending classical texts and proper name formation.
keyPoints: Categories: منقول، مرتجل، غلبة، لقب، كنية

notes.title: The Transferred Name (العلم المنقول)
content: الْعَلَمُ الْمَنْقُول is a proper noun 'transferred' or borrowed from another word class. The original word had a meaning, and that form was then used as a name for a specific entity.
Sources of transferred names include: verbs (يَزِيدُ from يَزِيدُ 'he increases'), adjectives (سَعِيد from سَعِيد 'happy'), participles (حَامِد from حَامِد 'praiser'), nouns (أَسَد 'lion' as a name).

notes.title: The Original Name (العلم المرتجل)
content: الْعَلَمُ الْمُرْتَجَل is a proper noun that was coined specifically as a name from the beginning. It was not transferred from any other word - it was invented purely as a name.
These names have no independent meaning outside being names. Examples include some ancient Arab names whose original meaning is unknown or non-existent.

notes.title: Names by Predominance (العلم بالغلبة)
content: الْعَلَمُ بِالْغَلَبَةِ is when a descriptive phrase becomes so associated with one entity that it functions as a proper noun. The name 'prevails' (غَلَبَة) for that specific referent.
Examples: الْكِتَاب for the Quran, الْمَدِينَة for Medina, الْبَيْت for the Kaaba, ابْنُ عَبَّاس for Abdullah ibn Abbas. The article أل is retained because it's part of the established name.
keyPoints: أل retained as part of name

notes.title: The Nickname and Teknonym (اللقب والكنية)
content: اللَّقَب is a nickname or title given to a person, often describing a quality, achievement, or characteristic. It can be positive (مدح) or negative (ذم). Examples: الصِّدِّيق (the truthful) for Abu Bakr, الْفَارُوق (the distinguisher) for Umar.
الْكُنْيَة is a teknonym - a name formed with أَبُو (father of) or أُمّ (mother of). Examples: أَبُو بَكْر، أُمّ سَلَمَة. The كُنْيَة may not refer to an actual child - it can be honorific.
keyPoints: كُنْيَة may be honorific, not literal

notes.title: Order of Name Components
content: When a person has multiple name components, the traditional order is: كُنْيَة (Abu/Umm...) + اسم (given name) + لَقَب (nickname) + نَسَب (lineage). However, لَقَب can sometimes precede اسم if the لَقَب is more famous.
In construct chains: if لَقَب and اسم are both mentioned, the second is بَدَل (apposition). Modern naming conventions may differ from classical patterns.
keyPoints: Traditional order: كُنْيَة، اسم، لَقَب، نَسَب
لَقَب may precede اسم if more famous
Second element is بَدَل in construct

examples.arabic: أَبُو الْقَاسِمِ مُحَمَّدُ بْنُ عَبْدِ اللهِ
examples.english: Abu al-Qasim Muhammad ibn Abdullah (full name)
Commander of Believers Umar ibn al-Khattab

exercises.prompt: الْعَلَمُ الَّذِي أُخِذَ مِنْ كَلِمَةٍ أُخْرَى يُسَمَّى الْعَلَمَ _____
exercises.promptEn: A proper noun taken from another word is called a _____ name

exercises.prompt: الْعَلَمُ الَّذِي وُضِعَ مِنَ الْبِدَايَةِ اسْمًا دُونَ نَقْلٍ يُسَمَّى الْعَلَمَ _____
exercises.promptEn: A proper noun coined originally as a name is called a _____ name

exercises.prompt: الْكِتَاب بِمَعْنَى الْقُرْآن هُوَ عَلَمٌ بِ_____
exercises.promptEn: الْكِتَاب meaning the Quran is a name by _____
Al-Siddiq and Al-Faruq are examples of _____

exercises.prompt: أَبُو بَكْرٍ وَأُمُّ سَلَمَةَ مِنْ أَمْثِلَةِ _____
exercises.promptEn: Abu Bakr and Umm Salamah are examples of _____

exercises.prompt: اسْمُ يَزِيدُ عَلَمٌ _____ مِنَ الْفِعْلِ يَزِيدُ
exercises.promptEn: The name Yazid is a _____ name from the verb يَزِيدُ

exercises.answer: A transferred name (taken from another word)
A name by predominance (strongly associated with one entity)
A teknonym (name with Abu/Umm - father/mother of)

exercises.prompt: A proper noun coined specifically as a name from the start
A nickname or title given to describe a quality or achievement
A descriptive phrase that becomes so associated with one entity it functions as a name
